document.title: Rehabilitation of Post Concussion Syndrome
document.section: Case Study - Rehabilitation of Post Concussion Syndrome

Abstract This page is for educational purposes, and outlines a fictional case study of a 19-year old female athlete experiencing concussion, and subsequently post-concussion syndrome. The patient presents in a complex manner as she has experienced several recent concussions prior to the one in question. During the case, she develops persistent symptoms and psychosocial comorbidities that – as suggested in the literature[1][2]– make diagnosis and treatment more complicated. The purpose of this case study is to provide an overview of the condition and its broad range of possible symptoms, describe a unique presentation of the condition, discuss assessment methods, and present relevant treatment approaches used to achieve the patient’s goal of returning to school and sport. The patient participates in a course of physiotherapy to treat difficulties with balance, vision, cognition, fainting, pain, strength, and cervical mobility.

Introduction As a condition that has become increasingly researched and well-understood in recent years,post-concussion syndromeis something that all physiotherapists should be familiar with and prepared to treat. Post-concussion syndrome describes persistent cognitive and physical symptoms beyond the typical 1-3 month period during which most concussions recover[3]. As the literature has developed, it has become recognized that 10-30% of mild head trauma may result in symptoms that last for months to years[1]. With this in mind, physiotherapists must be vigilant in recognizing when a patient is likely experiencing the condition.

Client Characteristics A 19-year old female playing for Team Ontario ringette suffered a contre-coup blow to the head during a scrimmage in practice. The patient collided with another teammate, crashing head-first into the ice. Initially, she did not feel any different other than experiencing some dizziness, but reported that she began experiencing extreme nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness and double vision the following day. Over the next two weeks, she was closely monitored by doctors while attempting to continue living in residence at university, however she was sent home following an increase of 10 points in her SCAT5 symptom score from day 1 post-injury to day 14. Once at home, she was dark roomed for long periods of time until deemed stable to return to school. She experienced several relapses in her recovery and often experienced fainting spells lasting as long as one hour from continuous studying and attempts at physical activity. She reported that she had previously suffered three minor concussions in the last 8 months. She noted that her recovery time has increased from the first concussion (1 week) to the third concussion (3 weeks), however each time she followed a return to play protocol set out by her coaches. Since her concussion symptoms have been present and persisting for over 3 months prior to the initial assessment with the author, she was therefore diagnosed with Post-Concussion Syndrome (PCS) by her sports medicine doctor. She has decided to attempt physiotherapy upon request from her doctor to see if she can reduce her symptoms and increase her quality of life.

Examination Findings On examination, she subjectively spoke about the pain that she was experiencing. She explained that in the absence of light and activity, she had dull, achy headaches resulting in a 4/10 on the NPRS scale. However, with increased light, noise, reading and neck pain, her headaches become sharp and shooting from the base of her neck into her skull, resulting in a 8/10 on the NPRS scale. Sleep was not affected, and she often described it as being her only moments of relief. It was also very apparent that she was experiencing an identity crisis as her lifelong athletic career was suddenly over, characterized by emotional responses[4]such as depression, loss of sense of self and anger. She often mentioned that she did not know who she was without her sport, and was very angry towards her situation and the girl who injured her. Her family also noted changes in her personality including introvertedness, depression, anxiety, and loss of emotional control. She had been a highly functioning young woman previously, a competitive ringette player who practiced at least 5 times per week in addition to completing her degree in Kinesiology. Her main objective was to continue to pursue her degree while also continuing to play top-level ringette, with the hope of medaling at the National Ringette Championships. With this most recent injury, her chief concern is to be able to return to school with strategies to minimize aggravating factors/symptoms while attempting to complete her degree. She was able to study for moderate amounts of time (20-30 minutes with breaks) however long-term studying needed for exams caused major PCS symptoms such as dizziness, nausea, vomiting and fainting. She was still able to manage independently in residence, and would only have moderate trouble taking transportation (cars, buses, etc.).

Objective Assessment TheSport Concussion Assessment Tool 5th Edition (SCAT-5)[5]was completed by the Team Ontario trainers immediately following the impact and a copy of the results were given to the physiotherapist for reference. The SCAT-5 is the most current version of the SCAT assessment tool used to screen for presence of concussions in sport settings. The SCAT-5 addresses the following subtopics[5]:
Athlete Background
Symptom Evaluation
Cognitive Screening (Orientation, Immediate Memory, Concentration)
Neurological Screen & Balance Examination
Delayed Recall
Decision

Clinical Hypothesis/Impression A major problem that the patient faced during rehabilitation was the inability to gradually return to school due to the high demand of a bachelor of science program. This was affecting her progression as she would often experience a relapse of symptoms when studying for exams or attempting to complete assignments. Furthermore, the forward head posture often demonstrated by students while studying was aggravating already strained neck muscles (whiplash during injury), further contributing to her daily headaches. The combination of an incessant workload at school and the severity of her symptoms due to repeated impacts to her head (4 concussions in 8 months) was having negative psychological effects, adding to her already altered/heightened psychological state as she was working through her identity crisis. The pain, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, diplopia and fainting that she would often experience as a result of exertion was not only disabling but was also very unnerving for a student living alone and away from home. Patient is a previously high functioning athlete and 19 y/o university student with her 4th concussion in 8 months who presents with pain, nausea, dizziness, fainting, nystagmus, poor balance, poor memory recall, decreased movement of the neck and personality changes. Due to the number of concussions in a short period of time and the severity of the patients persisting symptoms, the focus will be on return to school as return to sport is not foreseen, nor advised. Excellent candidate for physiotherapy activities aimed at increasing balance, range, VOR and proprioception; functional mobility, and optimizing participation in activities suitable for the patients return to school protocol.

Intervention The treatment program was designed based on the patients assessment findings and will be completed to the patients level of tolerance, following a similar protocol toFowler-Kennedy Guidelines[3]. These should not exceed patients limitations and should not cause the reproduction of the patients symptoms or fatigue in the first few sessions.

Treatment for Balance and Visual Processing A component of the treatment plan will include interventions to address the limitations in balance, postural control and dizziness/associated visual tracking limitations, following a similar protocol to theFowler-Kennedy guidelines[3]. The balance limitations will be addressed first working on basic balance exercises and then adding progressions to these exercises as follows:
Basic balance exercises Progression of basic balance exercises
2 feet balance to single leg balanceChanging the surface (firm to foam surfaces)Eyes open and eyes closed Changing incline of the surface (eyes opened & closed)Add internal perturbations (moving limbs or changing base of support)Add a dual task component (adding cognitive tasks while maintaining balance)
Furthermore, thevisual tracking/dizziness limitations[10]will be addressed through various vestibular, visual, and vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) exercises which may include the following:
Substitution exercises: moving eyes to a target first and then moving the head
VOR exercises: keep focused on target while shaking head back and forth - do it by moving head side to side, up and down
Once balance and VOR factors have been addressed they can actually be combined in order to increase the level of difficulty within the tolerance of the patient[3]. For example, standing on a bosu-ball (challenging balance) while keeping eyes focused on a target while moving head back and forth.

Return to School Protocol UsingOntario Practice Guidelines for Concussion/Mild Traumatic Brain Injury & Persistent Symptoms[2]andSCAT 5[5], we can work towards implementing a graduated return to school protocol for the patient. Currently she has identified that she can study for approximately 20-30 minutes before causing symptoms however long periods of studying reproduces symptoms. By having graded exposure to studying and screen time within the tolerance level of the patient (meaning that symptoms are not reproduced), we can work towards gradually increasing the amount of time that she is able to study without the onset of symptoms[3]. For example, we would have the patient sit down to study and time how long it takes until her symptoms come on and use this as a framework. If symptoms arose with 20 minutes of studying at her desk, we would take 20% of this measure and therefore, have the patient study for 15-17 minutes an hour until she can go a week with no symptoms.

Outcome After two months of treatment by her physiotherapist, the patient has exhibited significant improvements since her initial appointment. Her SCAT5 score was routinely re-assessed to monitor changes on a weekly basis and overall has significantly improved including an increase from 10 seconds on the Romberg test with eyes closed to 25 seconds. Marked improvements in convergence, Vestibulo-Occular Reflex, and an overall reduction in severity as well as prevalence of symptoms (nystagmus, diplopia, dizziness, nausea etc) were also noted. The patient’s balance and proprioception was challenged by the use of numerous different techniques in her treatment plan. After two months of treatment and home exercise prescription, the patient was able to demonstrate her ability to balance 30 seconds with eyes open, closed, and on various surfaces and inclines. Tandem balance has improved however is still challenging. The patient’s limited cervical range of motion and myofascial tone was addressed in treatment through the use of soft tissue release, motor control exercises, postural correction, and neck proprioception training. As a result, the patient’s neck range of motion in all directions has improved to within normal limits since her initial assessment. The patient’s NPRS score at the time of reassessment was also reduced to 0/10 during rest and at 2/10 at its worst.
Cognitive improvements were also subjectively noted. However, memory and cognition was not a direct focus of the physical therapy intervention and therefore cannot be inferred that improvements were a direct result of the treatment. CBMS Score:60/96 where MCID = 8[6] The patient shows marked improvements in overall balance and mobility based on her CBMS score. Based on the MCID, the change from initial assessment to the result in her re-assessment are clinically relevant. PHQ-9 Score:7 (Mild)[7] The patient is now below the cut score of clinically significant depression, however she still reports depressive attitudes towards her condition. As mentioned previously, it is not within PT scope of practice to diagnose mental illness so the change in score should be interpreted and monitored by a physician. Due to the degree of psychological distress the patient was dealing with as a result of her condition and the inability to return to sport, she was referred to a counsellor for a mental health consultation. The patient has also been diligently following the Return to School Protocol[2], requiring a licensed healthcare professional (physiotherapist) to sign off on each stage of the graded program. The patient no longer has difficulty managing her symptoms with her school workload, therefore the patient is deemed fit to return to school on a full-time basis[2].

Discussion Overall, this case study presents a complex case of Post-Concussion Syndrome. Due to her history of multiple recent concussions, the patient experienced almost all of the symptoms that are typically associated with PCS. As a result, the treatment intervention had a broad focus including balance, mobility, visual exercises, postural correction, strengthening, and a return to school protocol. The patient's development of significant psychosocial comorbidities further complicated her recovery, which is not unusual[11]. Her depressive symptoms, anxiety, and identity crisis were beyond the comfort level of the treating physiotherapist, so referral to a counsellor for mental health consultation was indicated. Comparing the outcome measures used before and after the intervention, it can be concluded that the patient benefitted substantially from physiotherapy treatment. To varying degrees, all outcomes improved following treatment suggesting that physiotherapists - among a variety of other healthcare professionals - should be included in the care of individuals similar to the patient in this case study. Ultimately, it is important to individualize care for individuals with PCS based on their symptoms and this care should be modified accordingly based on the patient's unique symptom progression or prognosis[2]. Since this page describes only one individual, it should be noted that the outcome measures and intervention methods selected are some of many valid and reliable tools that may be used in the treatment of PCS. If a patient presents similarly to the one in this case, physiotherapists may find success from using some or all of the protocol above.
